channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Police in India Plan to Question Editor Over Sexual Assault Accusation
item.description: Police officials from Goa are investigating whether the editor, Tarun Tejpal, an anticorruption crusader, sexually assaulted a colleague.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Afghan Council Approves Security Pact, but Karzai Withholds His Signature
item.description: Leaders who had gathered in Kabul asked President Hamid Karzai on Sunday to sign the agreement promptly, but Mr. Karzai said that he wanted to continue negotiations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Thousands of Ukrainians Protest Scrapping of Trade Pact With E.U.
item.description: Marchers in Kiev angrily denounced the government’s decision to abandon broad political and free trade agreements with Europe, which were due to be signed this week.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Deals at Climate Meeting Advance Global Effort
item.description: Delegates agreed to the outlines of a system for pledging emissions cuts and supported a new treaty mechanism to tackle the human costs of global warming.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY

item.title: News Analysis: A Step, if Modest, Toward Slowing Iran’s Weapons Capability
item.description: The interim deal brings the Obama administration a step closer to its ultimate goal: lengthening the time it takes Iran to build a weapon.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: President Obama made a statement Saturday night from the White House.

item.title: Israeli Leaders Decry Geneva Accord
item.description: Officials said that they were not bound by the agreement on Iran’s nuclear program and that Israel would be ready to defend itself without assistance from allies.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Accord Reached With Iran to Halt Nuclear Program
item.description: The United States and five other world powers announced an accord that would temporarily freeze Tehran’s nuclear program and lay the foundation for a more sweeping deal.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Mohammad Javad Zarif, the Iranian foreign minister, left, with Catherine Ashton, the European Union’s top foreign policy official; Secretary of State John Kerry; and Laurent Fabius, the French foreign minister.

item.title: Syrian Rebels Seize Control of Oil Field From Assad
item.description: A group of rebel brigades captured a large oil and gas field from government forces, opposition activists said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Women in Domestic Slavery Case Lived in a ‘Collective’ With Suspect, Police Say
item.description: Two of three women who say they were held for 30 years in a London home had lived in a group with a suspect in the case, the police said.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD and STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Sunnis Close Baghdad Mosques to Challenge Religious Attacks
item.description: A move to shutter the sect’s mosques indefinitely as a protest tactic highlights Iraq’s deepening sectarian rift.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Captain of Seized Greenpeace Ship Speaks From Russia
item.description: The American captain said the Russian commandos who boarded the ship in September were coldly professional at first, but then plundered the crew’s alcohol supply.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Peter Willcox, right, the captain of a Greenpeace ship boarded by Russian commandos in September, was released on bail.

item.title: Thousands in Pakistan Protest American Drone Strikes
item.description: Demonstrators at a rally in Peshawar on Saturday vowed to stop NATO supply trucks unless the attacks ended.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD and IHSANULLAH TIPU MEHSUD

item.title: Syria Seen as Most Dire Refugee Crisis in a Generation
item.description: The Syrian war has created a refugee crisis bigger than the one unleashed by the Rwandan genocide, and humanitarian groups and governments say they expect it to go on for years.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: For Sale: Craggy Isle Where Olympic Rocks Are the Stars
item.description: Ailsa Craig, an uninhabited 200-acre island off the Scottish coast, is the source of a distinctive granite put to use every four years for Olympic Curling.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olympic curling stones come from rare granite quarried on the island of Ailsa Craig, an uninhabited Scottish island. It can be yours for $2.4 million.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Fighter of Corruption in Nigeria Considers Next Steps
item.description: Nuhu Ribadu, who has been celebrated inside Nigeria and beyond for his five-year tenure as chief of an anticorruption unit, has not ruled out a bid for the presidency.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:credit: Afolabi Sotunde for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nuhu Ribadu, Nigeria’s anticorruption commissioner, on Friday.

item.title: Son of Israeli Ex-President Takes Helm of Labor Party, Urging Peace
item.description: Isaac Herzog, the son of former President Chaim Herzog, urged “bold steps” toward peace with the Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Isaac Herzog in Tel Aviv on Friday, after becoming chairman of the Labor Party. He will also lead Parliament’s opposition.

item.title: Karzai Insists U.S. Forces Killed Civilians in a Raid
item.description: After announcing he would delay signing a deal he had agreed to, Hamid Karzai began a new quarrel with Americans, over a recent raid.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Hamid Karzai spoke at the opening of a council meeting, surprising many listeners when he said he would delay signing a crucial deal.

item.title: Forgotten Killer Among the Korean ‘Erased’
item.description: A book is a requiem for the thousands of young men from both Koreas who were trained as secret fighters of the Cold War, and then disowned by North and South.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ra Jong-yil, a former deputy director of South Korean intelligence, has written a book about the grim fate of a North Korean agent.

item.title: A Growing Chill Between South Korea and Japan Creates Problems for the U.S.
item.description: The current tensions are an increasingly vexing problem for the Obama administration as it struggles to present a united front in dealing with a rising China and a nuclear North Korea.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER and CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea is under constant pressure to distance herself from her father’s ties to Japan.

item.title: Bodies Still Being Found Weeks After Philippine Storm
item.description: Weeks after a typhoon devastated a chunk of the Philippines, bodies continue to be found amid the piles of debris, gruesome reminders of tragedy.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Athena Mae Pelingon, 3, was buried by relatives at a local cemetery. Her body was found under a pile of debris only recently.

item.title: Editor in India, Known for Investigations Into Corruption, Is Accused of Rape
item.description: Rape and sexual assault charges have been filed against Tarun Tejpal, the editor of Tehelka, a liberal-minded magazine that has influenced a generation of young Indian journalists.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: China Claims Air Rights Over Disputed Islands
item.description: The Chinese government warned that it claimed the right to possibly take military action against aircraft that enter a newly declared “air defense identification zone,” which covers sea and islands also claimed by Japan.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: A Gamble in Iran Talks: Easing of the Sanctions
item.description: President Obama’s critics — in Congress, the Arab world and Israel — argue that he has the strategy backward in negotiating a freeze of Iran’s nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Mohammad Javad Zarif is Iran’s foreign minister and chief negotiator in talks on his country’s nuclear program.

item.title: Egypt Expels Turkish Ambassador
item.description: Egypt downgraded diplomatic relations with Turkey and ordered its ambassador expelled from Cairo, a sharp escalation in tensions between the two countries that have mounted since Mohammed Morsi’s ouster.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Egypt Expels Turkey’s Ambassador, Further Fraying Diplomatic Ties
item.description: Egypt cited “provocative” criticisms by Turkey, and Turkey announced reciprocal steps.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and SEBNEM ARSU
